{{Infobox book | name = A New Philosophy of Society: Assemblage Theory and Social Complexity | image = File:A New Philosophy of Society.jpg | image_size = 200px | author = [[Manuel DeLanda]] | country = | language = English | subject = [[Ontology]] | published = 2006 | pages = 150 | isbn = 978-0826491695 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = }} '''''A New Philosophy of Society: Assemblage Theory and Social Complexity''''' is a 2006 book by [[Manuel DeLanda]].<ref name="Karaman">Karaman, Ozar: "Book Review" in ''Antipode'', November 2008</ref> The book is an attempt to loosely define a new [[ontology]] for use by [[social theory|social theorists]] — one that challenges the existing [[paradigm]] of meaningful social analyses being possible only on the level of either individuals (micro-reductionism) or "society as a whole" (macro-reductionism). Instead, the book employs [[Gilles Deleuze]]'s [[Assemblage theory|theory of assemblages]] from ''[[A Thousand Plateaus]]'' (1980) to posit social entities on all scales (from sub-individual to transnational) that are best analysed through their components (themselves assemblages).
==Main ideas== Components are characterized along two primary axes/dimensions: a material-expressive axis which defines the variable roles a component may play, and a [[Reterritorialization|territorializing]]-[[Deterritorialization|deterritorializing]] axis indicating processes in which a component is involved. These components are defined by relations of [[exteriority]], that is, their "role" within a larger assemblage is not what defines them (this would be a relation of interiority). This means that a component is self-subsistent and may be "unplugged" from one assemblage and "plugged" into another without losing its identity. A third axis defines processes in which specialized expressive media (genetic/linguistic resources) intervene in "coding"/"decoding" the assemblage.
According to DeLanda, following Deleuze's ideas of [[difference and repetition]] (what DeLanda calls "variable repetition"), assemblages necessarily exist in [[heterogeneous]] populations. The relationship between an assemblage and its components is complex and [[Nonlinear system|non-linear]]: assemblages are formed and affected by heterogeneous populations of lower-level assemblages, but may also act back upon these components, imposing restraints or adaptations in them.
DeLanda merges Deleuze's ideas of both assemblages and strata into his model of assemblages, regarding the distinction as inconsequential in the context of ''A New Philosophy of Society''. He does however maintain the idea of assemblages as non-essentialist (they are historically contingent actual entities, not instances of ideal forms) and non-totalizing (assemblages are not seamless totalities but collections of heterogeneous components that should be analysed as such).
==Examples== As an example of an assemblage (as defined by DeLanda) consider an ecosystem:
* The material role here is performed by the soil, sunlight, trees, animals, etc. * The expressive role is performed by the forms, colours, habits, etc. of the aforementioned components. * The territorializing role would be played by factors such as [[food chains]], [[adaptive traits]], conducive climate and other elements that maintain the components and their relationships and thus the identity and durability of the assemblage. * The deterritorializing role would be played by such factors as [[climate change]], [[invasion]] by exotic species, evolutionary [[mutation]] and other elements that recombine or replace various components and roles within the assemblage, leading to its dissipation or reformulation. * A linguistic/coding role could be played by an environmental discourse seeking to protect an [[ecosystem]].
Consistent with DeLanda's [[materialist]] position, the book also includes as a secondary task a sustained criticism of the primacy of post-modernist linguistic analysis in [[social science]] (the theory of the linguistics of experience).
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== DeLanda, Manuel (2006) ''[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=TkISBwAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&dq=A%20New%20Philosophy%20of%20Society%20%3A%20assemblage%20theory%20and%20social%20complexity&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false A New Philosophy of Society: assemblage theory and social complexity]'', London & New York: Continuum
{{Deleuze-Guattari}}

[[Johns Hopkins University]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Quorum sensing]] | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Wiley Prize|Wiley Prize in Biomedical Science]] (2009)
[[Richard Lounsbery Award]] {{small|(2011)}}
[[Shaw Prize]] {{small|(2015)}}
[[Pearl Meister Greengard Prize]] {{small|(2016)}}
[[Fellow of the Royal Society]]{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Professor Bonnie L. Bassler ForMemRS | publisher = [[The Royal Society]] | date = | url = http://royalsociety.org/people/bonnie-bassler/ | format = | accessdate = 2012-10-21}} | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Bonnie Lynn Bassler''', Ph.D (born 1962) is an American [[Molecular biology|molecular biologist]] who revolutionized [[microbiology]] with her discovery of the use of chemical communication between bacteria known as [[quorum sensing]], as well as the idea that disruption of chemical signaling could be used as an antimicrobial therapy. She is a professor at [[Princeton University]] and [[Howard Hughes Medical Institute]] in microbiology and [[virology]] with a research focus in cell-to-cell communication in [[bacteria]] {{Cite web|url=https://molbio.princeton.edu/people/bonnie-l-bassler|title=Bonnie Bassler at Princeton|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. She received the [[Wiley Prize in Biomedical Sciences]] (2009), the [[Richard Lounsbery Award]] (2011), and the [[L'Oréal-UNESCO For Women in Science Awards|L’Oreal-UNESCO]] award (2012), the [[MacArthur Fellowship]]{{cite web|url=http://www.macfound.org/fellows/679/|title=MacArthur Foundation|website=www.macfound.org}} (2002){{Cite web|url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2002/09/25/biologist-bonnie-bassler-receives-macarthur-fellowship|title=Princeton university news|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, the [[Pearl Meister Greengard Prize]] (2016){{Cite news|url=https://molbio.princeton.edu/news/bassler-awarded-pearl-meister-greengard-prize|title=Princeton news|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} for her paradigm-changing scientific research and was made a member of the Royal Society and the [[American Philosophical Society]] in 2012. She sits on the [[National Science Board]] and was nominated to that position by [[Barack Obama]]. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Chicago]] and raised in [[Danville, California]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Ahmed | first1 = F. | title = Profile of Bonnie L. Bassler | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0705870105 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 105 | issue = 13 | pages = 4969–4971 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18362352 | pmc =2278219 }} Bassler received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[biochemistry]] from the [[University of California, Davis]] and a [[Ph.D.]] in biochemistry from [[Johns Hopkins University]].{{cite web|title=Bonnie L. Bassler, Ph.D.|url=http://www.hhmi.org/research/investigators/bassler_bio.html|work=Howard Hughes Medical Institute|accessdate=May 20, 2011}} She made key insights into the mechanism by which [[bacteria]] communicate,{{Cite journal | last1 = Schauder | first1 = S. | last2 = Bassler | first2 = B. L. | title = The languages of bacteria | doi = 10.1101/gad.899601 | journal = Genes & Development | volume = 15 | issue = 12 | pages = 1468–80 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11410527| pmc = }} known as [[quorum sensing]]. Her postdoctoral research was conducted at Agouron Institute in genetics before joining the Princeton faculty in 1994. ==Honors and awards== Bassler was elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] in 2006. She was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2007.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter B|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterB.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=May 20, 2011}} In 2008, she received a special recognition from the [[World Cultural Council]].{{cite web|title=Special Recognitions 2008|publisher=[[World Cultural Council]]|url=http://www.consejoculturalmundial.org/memories-ceremony2008-SpecialRecognitions.php|accessdate=August 19, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105183105/http://www.consejoculturalmundial.org/memories-ceremony2008-SpecialRecognitions.php|archivedate=November 5, 2013|df=}} She is an elected member of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] since 2004,{{Cite news|url=https://www.aaas.org/elected-fellows|title=Elected Fellows|date=2016-10-21|work=AAAS - The World's Largest General Scientific Society|access-date=2017-03-10|language=en}} and a member in the [[American Philosophical Society]] since 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amphilsoc.org/members|title=Members {{!}} American Philosophical Society|website=www.amphilsoc.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-10}} Bonnie Bassler served as a president of the [[American Society for Microbiology]] in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.asm.org/index.php/component/content/article/71-membership/archives/913-presidents-of-the-society?highlight=YTozOntpOjA7czo2OiJib25uaWUiO2k6MTtzOjc6ImJhc3NsZXIiO2k6MjtzOjE0OiJib25uaWUgYmFzc2xlciI7fQ==|title=American Society for Microbiology|website=www.asm.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-03-10}} Bonnie Bassler was nominated by President Barack Obama to the [[National Science Board]], and she served in that role for six years (2010-2016).{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/nsb/members/former.jsp|title=National Science Board|website=National Science Board|access-date=2017-03-10}} Bassler has been nominated by the [[American Society for Microbiology]] to be one of the [[USA Science and Engineering Festival#Nifty Fifty|USA Science and Engineering Festival's Nifty Fifty Speakers]] who will speak about her work and career to middle and high school students in October 2010.{{cite web |last= |first= |last2= |first2= |title=The Nifty Fifty (times 2) |publisher=[[USA Science and Engineering Festival]] |year=2010 |url=http://www.usasciencefestival.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=74&Itemid=95 |format= |accessdate=2012-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723105635/http://www.usasciencefestival.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=74&Itemid=95 |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }} The Nifty Fifty is a collection of the most influential scientists and engineers in the United States, that are dedicated to reinvigorating the interest of young people in science and engineering.[http://www.usasciencefestival.org/2012festival/schoolprograms/niftyfifty USA Science & Engineering Festival's Nifty Fifty] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629005707/http://www.usasciencefestival.org/2012festival/schoolprograms/niftyfifty |date=2011-06-29 }} She has won the [[Wiley Prize|Wiley prize]] in Biomedical Sciences in 2009 for "pioneering investigations of quorum sensing, a mechanism that allows bacteria to “talk” to each other to coordinate their behavior, even between species."{{Cite news|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/PressRelease/pressReleaseId-49205.html|title=Eighth Annual Wiley Prize in Biomedical Sciences Awarded to Dr. Bonnie Bassler of Princeton University|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/Section/id-390061.html|title=Wiley Foundation Past winners|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} In 2011, she won a [[Richard Lounsbery Award]] "For her pioneering discoveries of the universal use of chemical communication among bacteria and the elucidation of structural and regulatory mechanisms controlling bacterial assemblies." {{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/programs/awards/richard-lounsbery-award.html?referrer=https://www.google.com/|title=Richard Lounsbery Award|last=http://www.nasonline.org|first=National Academy of Sciences -|website=www.nasonline.org|access-date=2017-03-10}} Bonnie Bassler was named 2011 [[L'Oréal-UNESCO Awards for Women in Science|L'Oréal-UNESCO]] For Women in Science Awards Laureate for North America{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WsK7NUR-I9Y&feature=share&list=PLAAAAD435A2370CD7|title=Bonnie Bassler, 2012 L'Oréal-UNESCO Awards Laureate for North America|last=L’Oréal Foundation|date=26 March 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}} and received the Royal Society Fellowship Award the following year. She received honorary degrees from Tufts University and Bates College also in 2012. In 2014, Bassler was awarded the Excellence in Teaching Award and EMD Millipore Alice C. Evans Award{{Cite web|url=https://www.asm.org/index.php/awards2/21-awards-a-grants/current-laureates/86-current-emd-millipore-alice-c-evans-award-laureate|title=2014 EMD Millipore Alice C. Evans Award Laureate|website=www.asm.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-20}} both from the American Society for Microbiology and the Excellence in Teaching Award by Phi Beta Kappa{{Cite news|url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2014/05/29/two-princeton-professors-receive-phi-beta-kappa-teaching-awards|title=Two Princeton professors to receive Phi Beta Kappa teaching awards|work=Princeton University|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en}}. In 2015 she and [[Everett Peter Greenberg]] of the [[University of Washington]] were awarded the [[Shaw Prize]] in Life Science and Medicine "for elucidating the molecular mechanism of quorum sensing, a process whereby bacteria communicate with each other and which offers innovative ways to interfere with bacterial pathogens or to modulate the microbiome for health applications."{{cite web|url=http://www.shawprize.org/en/shaw.php?tmp=3&twoid=98&threeid=244&fourid=439|title=Shaw Laureates in 2015 in Life Science and Medicine: Announcement and Citation|publisher=Shaw Prize Foundation|accessdate=2 June 2015}} In 2016, Bonnie Bassler was awarded The [[FASEB Excellence in Science Award]],{{Cite web|url=http://faseb.org/About-FASEB/Awards/Excellence-in-Science-Award/Recipients-and-Award-Lectures.aspx|title=Recipients and Award Lectures|website=faseb.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-10}} the Greengard prize{{Cite web|url=http://benchmarks.rockefeller.edu/2016/12/13/molecular-biologist-bonnie-bassler-receives-rockefellers-pearl-meister-greengard-prize/|title=Molecular biologist Bonnie Bassler receives Rockefeller's Pearl Meister Greengard Prize {{!}} The Rockefeller University Benchmarks|last=Alex|last2=MacWade|first2=ra|access-date=2017-03-10|last3=Editor|first3=Assistant|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312044038/http://benchmarks.rockefeller.edu/2016/12/13/molecular-biologist-bonnie-bassler-receives-rockefellers-pearl-meister-greengard-prize/#|archive-date=2017-03-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{Cite web|url=https://greengardprize.rockefeller.edu/|title=The Pearl Meister Greengard Prize - The Rockefeller University|website=greengardprize.rockefeller.edu|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-10}}, and the Max Planck Research Award{{Cite web|url=https://www.aaas.org/news/aaas-fellow-bonnie-bassler-wins-2016-max-planck-research-award|title=AAAS Fellow Bonnie Bassler wins 2016 Max Planck Research Award|website=American Association for the Advancement of Science|language=en|access-date=2018-10-20}}. In 2016, she also became an elected member of the National Academy of Medicine{{Cite news|url=https://nam.edu/national-academy-of-medicine-elects-79-new-members/|title=National Academy of Medicine Elects 80 New Members - National Academy of Medicine|date=2016-10-17|work=National Academy of Medicine|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-US}}. Bassler was awarded the [http://www.dicksonprize.pitt.edu/ Dickson Prize]{{Cite web|url=http://www.dicksonprize.pitt.edu/recipients/2018-bassler.php|title=Bonnie Bassler, PhD|last=Webteam|first=University of Pittsburgh University Marketing Communications|website=www.dicksonprize.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-20}} and the [https://scheringstiftung.de/en/programm/lebenswissenschaften/preise/ernst-schering-preis/ Ernst Schering Prize]{{Cite web|url=https://scheringstiftung.de/en/programm/lebenswissenschaften/preise/ernst-schering-preis/ernst-schering-preis-2018/|title=Ernst Schering Prize 2018 – Schering Stiftung|website=scheringstiftung.de|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-20}} in March and September of 2018 respectively. == Notable publications == * Ng, W. L., & Bassler, B. L. (2009). Bacterial quorum-sensing network architectures. {{unreferenced|date=January 2011}} The '''Boston Collaborative Encyclopedia of Western Theology''' is a freely accessible encyclopedia composed mainly by graduate students of [[Boston University| Boston University's]] [[Modern Theology|Modern Western Theology]] seminars. It focuses on Christian theology, mainly from the Western world and is edited by Wesley J. Wildman, a professor at [[Boston University School of Theology]]. Several entries were consolidated from the work of multiple students by Derek Michaud.
==See also== * ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' * ''[[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' * [[List of online encyclopedias]]
==External links== * [http://people.bu.edu/wwildman/bce/ Boston Collaborate Encyclopedia of Western Theology]
{{Boston University}}
